```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE, warning = TRUE)

# Setup packages
library(rgbif)
library(tidyverse)
```

# File goal
This file is intended to gather GBIF records for species on the California Channel Islands, which will be used to update the Cal-IBIS repository. **Before getting started**, create a folder for the date at which you are doing the download (for example, "January2024"). 

The file location should look something like:
> "C:\Users\Josie\SBBG\Cal-IBIS\Methods for Updating Collections\SBBG-Cal-IBIS-GBIF\Data\**Month YY**"
or C:\Users\ketter\OneDrive - Santa Barbara Botanic Garden\gitit_surface\Cal-IBIS-GBIF\Data\January2024"

Capitalization matters here, so be careful and consistent. 

Then, within that folder, **create a "Raw" folder and "GBIFClean Data" folder** -- this is where all of your files will end up.

Finally, hit ctrl+F within here, and *replace all* of the previous date ("January2024") with the new date, the name of the MonthYear folder you just created.

# Gathering GBIF Data
To begin, we'll gather the data we're interested in from GBIF. We'll download several separate datasets - these will end up as .zip folders in the "Data/GBIF/MonthYear" folder we created, and will need to be unzipped later.

Run the first chunk below. The download will take a while. Be patient -- give it ~20 minutes before coming back and moving on to the next chunk. Josie suggests making a cup of nice tea and enjoying it while tidying your inbox.

The chunk below is very long, but will prep your data downloads for everything in the following order:
1. Reptiles
2. Mammals
3. Fungi
4. Arthropods
5. Plants
6. Amphibia
7. Aves
8. Fishes
9. Non-arthro inverts

*KJE note, Josie's account is still active with the user and password used in all the download functions below, so I am just keeping to using those credentials. Also to describe what the chunk below is doing, it is downloading all the spatial data from GBIF on the Channel Islands from the specified taxon. The lists of coordinates form polygons around all the islands and it is pulling all the occurrences within those polygons from any point in time. The taxonKey = a number that GBIF has assigned to that taxa, fish and non-arthropod inverts needed multiple taxonKeys to capture everything within "Fishes" and "Non-arthro inverts". The format = "DWCA" is the format the data is downloaded in, DarwinCore Archive (which has Raw data, Interpreted data, multimedia links, coordintes and it's a Tab-delimited CSV)


## Downloading zip files
Did you wait at least 20 minutes?

If you've waited, run the chunk below. The tibble it produces should show 9 datasets, and should show "succeeded" under "status". If it hasn't finished, indicates that things are still running, or that some requests haven't started, you should wait a little, and then check again (by running the chunk below again). 

If you get a failure message, need to troubleshoot. Remember to check that occurences were downloaded and taxonkeys are still right.

When the chunk below shows that all data has been prepared successfully, you're ready to move on. This chunk will also show the "keys" are associated with each of the 9 requests - in the reverse order that you made the requests in.

```{r show download list}
list <- as_tibble(occ_download_list(user = "jlesage", 
             pwd = "GBIF4SBBG", limit = 9))
```

You can now download the data! However, we need to make a few changes to the code below:

**BEFORE RUNNING THE CHUNK:** You'll need to change the keys (the long numbers in quotes) to reflect the keys shown by the chunk above - just copy and paste each of those nine below. *KJE note, I copied and pasted from the results$key column in the list dataframe. Do it in reverse order, so copy the bottom one first and put it in the first function below. This is to make sure that they are in the same order as the names, so you can easily name them without having to open up the raw data.

Also, make sure the date in the file path is correct!

Downloading the .zip files by running the code below will also take a small chunk of time -- be patient while the computer obtains all of the info.

```{r}

occ_download_get("0076118-231120084113126",
                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

occ_download_get("0076119-231120084113126",
                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

occ_download_get("0076121-231120084113126",
                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

occ_download_get("0076130-231120084113126",
                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")

                 overwrite = TRUE,
                 path = "Data/January2024/Raw")


```

Once all 9 zip folders are downloaded, you'll need to rename them for the correct group (i.e Mammals, Fungi, Plants etc) in your computer file browser (meaning this work can't happen in R). It's easiest to do this by comparing with the downloads list online:
https://www.gbif.org/user/download

The DOI url visible online should line up with the occ_download_list chunk above, and you'll be able to see exactly which groups were called on. 

Reminder that the downloads were as follows and this is how the folders should be names:
1. Reptiles
2. Mammals
3. Fungi
4. Arthropods
5. Plants
6. Amphibia
7. Aves
8. Fish
9. Inverts

Rename the .zip files in the folders to the correct group it belongs to using the GBIF link that shows the DOI (https://www.gbif.org/user/download), occ_download_list below, and the files in the folder. 

After renaming, extract the zip files. The folder should now be "DATE/Raw" with 9 folders (one for each group, as named above).

Congrats! You've completed step 1 of the process. Time to move on to step 2.
